originalTitle: More than 200 killed in mine collapse in DR Congo
title: Sad News and Helping Hands in DR Congo
content:
Hi everyone, it's your friendly news reporter, here to share some important news from our wonderful continent of Africa. Sometimes, news can make us feel a little sad, but it's important to know what's happening and how people are helping each other. Today, we have some sad news from a country called the Democratic Republic of Congo. Let's learn about it together, in a very gentle way.

What Happened in DR Congo?

Imagine a really big hole in the ground. People dig these holes to find special rocks and metals that we use for many things, like making phones, cars, and even some toys! These big holes are called mines. Well, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, or DR Congo for short, something very sad happened at one of these mines. There was a lot, a *lot* of rain. The rain poured down from the sky, making the ground very, very soft. Because the ground got so wet and soft, parts of the big hole, the mine, couldn't hold up anymore. It fell down, or 'collapsed'. This is very sad news.

A Lot of People Are Sad

When the mine collapsed, many people were inside. They were working hard, trying to find those special rocks. Sadly, because the mine fell down, more than 200 people lost their lives. That means they are no longer with us. This makes many, many families and friends in DR Congo very, very sad. Imagine how sad you would be if someone you loved was gone. That's how many people feel right now. We send our biggest hugs and warmest thoughts to everyone who is feeling sad in DR Congo.

What is a Mine, Really?

Let's talk a little more about mines. A mine is like a giant underground cave that people make. They use special tools to dig deep, deep into the Earth. They are looking for things like gold, diamonds, copper, and cobalt. These are very precious things that come from inside our planet. People work very hard in mines, and it can be a very difficult job. That's why it's so important that mines are always very safe places to work. We need strong walls and ceilings, just like your house needs strong walls and a roof to keep you safe. **Did you know?** Some mines can go down deeper than the tallest building in the world!

Where is DR Congo?

DR Congo is a really big country! It's right here in Africa, our home continent. It's one of the biggest countries in Africa, and it has lots of beautiful forests, big rivers, and friendly people. It's also famous for having many of those special rocks and metals we talked about earlier. People from all over the world sometimes buy these minerals from DR Congo. So, it's a very important country for many reasons. It's important to remember that even when sad things happen, DR Congo is a strong and beautiful place. **Did you know?** The Democratic Republic of Congo is sometimes called the 'heart of Africa' because it's so big and important!

How Heavy Rains Made Things Tricky

Think about when you build a sandcastle on the beach. If the sand is a little bit wet, it holds together really well, right? But if you pour a whole bucket of water on it, the sandcastle can sometimes melt or fall apart. It's a bit like that with the ground in the mine. The heavy rains were like pouring a giant bucket of water. The earth became too soft and weak. It couldn't hold up the big mine tunnels anymore, and that's why parts of it collapsed. It was a very big accident caused by nature's powerful rain. **Did you know?** Heavy rains are also called downpours or deluges, and they can make rivers overflow too!

Helping Hands Are Everywhere

Even though this news is very sad, there's always a lot of love and help when bad things happen. Right now, many people are working together to help in DR Congo. Doctors, nurses, and rescue workers are there, doing their very best. They are looking for anyone who might need help and taking care of the families who are sad. People from all over are sending kind words and support. It shows how strong we are when we work together and help each other. We are a big African family, and we care for each other. **Did you know?** When people help search for others after an accident, they are called 'rescuers' – they are very brave! **Did you know?** Minerals like copper are used to make the wires that carry electricity to your house and lights! So, even though we heard some very sad news today from DR Congo, we also learned about the power of helping. We learned about mines, about our big African continent, and about why safety is so important. Let's all send our kindest thoughts to the people of DR Congo. And remember, no matter what happens, we can always be kind, helpful, and learn from each other. That's all for now from your friendly African news reporter. Stay safe and be kind!
summary: Very sad news came from the Democratic Republic of Congo where a mine collapsed after heavy rains, causing many people to lose their lives, but many kind helpers are there to support everyone.
whyMatters: This matters because it shows us how important it is for workplaces like mines to be very, very safe, and how we all need to care for each other and help when sad things happen in our big African family.

originalTitle: This army chief threatened to castrate opposition leader and claimed descent from Jesus
title: This army chief threatened to castrate opposition leader and claimed descent from Jesus
content: The Ugandan president’s son, notorious for explosive remarks on X, has ambitions to  succeed his father.

originalTitle: Mali lawmaker jailed in Ivory Coast for insulting president
title: Mali lawmaker jailed in Ivory Coast for insulting president
content: Prosecutors say Mamadou Hawa Gassama described Alassane Ouattara as a "tyrant" and "an enemy of Mali".

originalTitle: Pakistan beat Australia to seal cricket series in T20 World Cup warm-up
title: Pakistan beat Australia to seal cricket series in T20 World Cup warm-up
content: Pakistan thump Australia by 90 runs in Lahore in second T20 of tour to seal three-match T20 series 2-0.

originalTitle: German football federation rules out World Cup boycott to oppose Trump
title: German football federation rules out World Cup boycott to oppose Trump
content: German football federation confirms it met to discuss a boycott of the FIFA 2026 World Cup, which is co-hosted by US.

originalTitle: Drone strikes in Ethiopia’s Tigray kill one amid fears of renewed conflict
title: Drone strikes in Ethiopia’s Tigray kill one amid fears of renewed conflict
content: The attack comes amid fears of a return to conflict following clashes between government troops and Tigrayan forces.

originalTitle: Takeaways from the millions of newly released Epstein files
title: Takeaways from the millions of newly released Epstein files
content: Three million new documents include hundreds of mentions of Trump and emails between Epstein and a person called "The Duke".

originalTitle: Pedro Pascal and Meryl Streep lead tributes to Catherine O'Hara
title: Pedro Pascal and Meryl Streep lead tributes to Catherine O'Hara
content: The Canadian comedic actress died in Los Angeles on Friday at the age of 71 following a brief illness.

originalTitle: Israeli air strikes kill at least 28 Palestinians in Gaza, rescue officials say
title: Israeli air strikes kill at least 28 Palestinians in Gaza, rescue officials say
content: Israel's military confirmed the strikes, which come during a ceasefire that Israel and Hamas accuse each other of breaking.

originalTitle: Forest agree Ortega deal and target Inter's Frattesi
title: Forest agree Ortega deal and target Inter's Frattesi
content: Nottingham Forest agree a deal for Manchester City goalkeeper Stefan Ortega worth up to £500,000.

title: I never stopped believing - Calvert-Lewin
content: Leeds striker Dominic Calvert-Lewin sits down with BBC Sport's Betty Glover to talk about his return to goalscoring form, being a free agent and his England chances.

originalTitle: Nine siblings and a dog called Zoomer - Wirtz in his own words
title: Nine siblings and a dog called Zoomer - Wirtz in his own words
content: Florian Wirtz sits down with Kelly Somers to talk about his slow start at Anfield, playing padel and making Bundesliga history.
